TypeSignature.Value: .class public auto ansi beforefieldinit UIResponder extends MonoTouch.Foundation.NSObject implements class MonoTouch.ObjCRuntime.INativeObject, class MonoTouch.UIKit.IUIPasteConfigurationSupporting, class System.IDisposable

Docs.summary: Base class for objects that respond or handle events.

remarks.para: This is the base class for (and by extension, ), and .

iOS implements a responder chain that allows various events (Touch events, device motion events, actions and menu editing options) to be handled at various levels depending on who is interested in handling the event.
When a touch takes place, the operating system packages the event and processes it like this:

item.term: The where the touch took place is determined by using the and the touch is sent to that view.
If the view did not handle the event, the message is sents to its if there is one, or to its if there is no view controller.
The process is repeated for each superview, until it reaches the topmost .
If the topmost UIWindow does not handle the event, the message is sent to the .

remarks.para: To receive messages UIResponders override the property to return true and are notified that they became the first responder when the is invoked. The system calls to notify a the first responder that the first responder is changing. Text input responders will typically override both methods to activate and deactivate the virtual keyboard.

For action messages, editing menu messages, remote events and motion events are sent to the designated first responder. These events, if they are not handled are bubbled up the responder chain by sending the message to the . Developers that override any of the UIResponder methods for these kinds of events should avoid directly calling the NextResponder methods, instead they should just call the base implementation which takes care of the proper event bubbling.

When an event is delivered to the topmost , if the event is not handled, it is sent to its container recursively. The container can be a, a , a or the . This allows developers to override the event handling methods at the level that is most convenient for them.
iOS creates a object any time a finger touches the screen, moves or is removed from the screen. The touch events are processed by the UIResponder by calling one of , , , and .

An encapsulates all of the touches that are taking place on the screen at this point, even those that do not belong to the particular view. In addition to the , an containing objects that represent the state of each finger on the screen is sent to the various Touch methods.
It is considered a good coding practice to override all of the touch event methods. If your application is tracking state in response to a or a they should reset their state on the and methods.

Device motion events are also delivered to UIResponders. These are generated when the device moves (shakes). The operating system calls the when the motion begins, the if the motion event is cancelled, and when the shaking stops. Shakes are aggregated.
In particular, bubbles the events up the responder chain.

Just like touch events, developers that override these methods are encouraged to override them all and ensure that any resources allocated during an initial motion event are properly disposed either during the MotionENded or MotionCancelled methods.
The following methods are part of the standard edit protocol. You can implement these in your UIResponder to participate in these standard operations: , , , , and .
The following methods are used to change the styling of text: , and .

If you are implementing a UIResponder subclass (like your own UIView) and you want it to display the standard editing menu, you must: override and return true, override the method and return true for all actions that you support and override the methods that actually carry out the action (the ones listed in "Standard Edit Actions" above)

MemberSignature.Value: .method public hidebysig specialname rtspecialname instance void .ctor() cil managed

Docs.summary: Default constructor that initializes a new instance of this class with no parameters.

MemberSignature.Value: .method familyhidebysig specialname rtspecialname instance void .ctor(class MonoTouch.Foundation.NSObjectFlag t) cil managed

Docs.param: Unused sentinel value, pass NSObjectFlag.Empty.
Docs.summary: Constructor to call on derived classes to skip initialization and merely allocate the object.

remarks.para: This constructor should be called by derived classes when they completely construct the object in managed code and merely want the runtime to allocate and initialize the NSObject. This is required to implement the two-step initialization process that Objective-C uses, the first step is to perform the object allocation, the second step is to initialize the object. When developers invoke the constructor that takes the NSObjectFlag.Empty they take advantage of a direct path that goes all the way up to NSObject to merely allocate the object's memory and bind the Objective-C and C# objects together. The actual initialization of the object is up to the developer.

This constructor is typically used by the binding generator to allocate the object, but prevent the actual initialization to take place. Once the allocation has taken place, the constructor has to initialize the object. With constructors generated by the binding generator this means that it manually invokes one of the "init" methods to initialize the object.
It is the developer's responsibility to completely initialize the object if they chain up using the NSObjectFlag.Empty path.

In general, if the developer's constructor invokes the NSObjectFlag.Empty base implementation, then it should be calling an Objective-C init method. If this is not the case, developers should instead chain to the proper constructor in their class.

The argument value is ignored and merely ensures that the only code that is executed is the construction phase is the basic NSObject allocation and runtime type registration. Typically the chaining would look like this:

MemberSignature.Value: .method familyorassemblyhidebysig specialname rtspecialname instance void .ctor(native int handle) cil managed

Docs.param: Pointer (handle) to the unmanaged object.
Docs.summary: A constructor used when creating managed representations of unmanaged objects; Called by the runtime.

remarks.para: This constructor is invoked by the runtime infrastructure () to create a new managed representation for a pointer to an unmanaged Objective-C object. Developers should not invoke this method directly, instead they should call the GetNSObject method as it will prevent two instances of a managed object to point to the same native object.

MemberSignature.Value: .method public hidebysig newslot virtual instance bool BecomeFirstResponder() cil managed

Docs.summary: Request the object to become the first responder.
Docs.returns: Returns true if the object accepts becoming the first responder, or false if it does not. The default is to accept.

remarks.para: You can overwrite this method to detect when your UIResponder object becomes the first responder and to either accept or reject the request.
Typically this method is invoked by application code to request that a specific object become the first responder. Typically to give the focus to a UIView, for example, to focus a or a .
It is possible for this call to fail if the current first responder refuses to give up control. This condition can be detected by probing the .
This method is only valid if invoked in a UIResponder that is part of the currently active responder chain. Sending this to a UIView that has not been added to a responder chain does nothing.

Docs.summary: Determines whether this UIREsponder is willing to become the first responder.

remarks.para: Developers that want to write UIResponders that are interested in receiving touch events or action messages must override this method and return true.

Docs.param: The selector that represents the action that is being probed. For editing operations, these selectors are "copy:", "cut:", "delete:", "paste:", "select:", "selectAll:", "toggleBoldface:", "toggleItalics:", "toggleUnderline:".
Docs.summary: Determines if this UIResponder can perform the specified action. Typically used to probe for editing commands.
Docs.returns: True if the specified action can be performed with the specified sender.

remarks.para: This method should return true if the action specified by the selector can be performed by the object.

Docs.summary: Determines whether this UIResponder is willing to give up its first responder status.
Docs.remarks: Developers can override this method if they want to prevent their view from relinquishing their first responder status.

Docs.summary: The handle for this class.
Docs.value: The pointer to the Objective-C class.
Docs.remarks: Each MonoTouch class mirrors an unmanaged Objective-C class. This value contains the pointer to the Objective-C class, it is similar to calling objc_getClass with the object name.

Docs.summary: Sent when one or more fingers touches the screen.

remarks.para: The set containing all of the touch events.
If your application tracks the touches starting with this method, it should also override both the and methods to track the end of the touch processing.
UIViews by default only receive a single touch event at once, if you want to receive multiple touches at the same time, set the property to true.
If you only want to handle a single touch, the following idiom can be used:
If you want to handle multiple touches, you can use this idiom:
